definition: Privacy protections and GLBA compliance for customer information accessed through online banking
organization_owner: and other electronic delivery channels. Includes data security
key_features: Per GLBA and electronic banking guidance, financial institutions providing Internet or electronic banking services must maintain safeguards and privacy protections for customer information accessed electronically. Electronic services include: online banking; mobile banking apps; electronic bill payment; electronic funds transfer; credit card systems; ATM access; online customer service; electronic account statements; digital wallets; payment processing. Privacy and security requirements apply equally to electronic channels: information security program applies to electronic systems; safeguards requirements apply to electronic information; privacy rule applies to electronically-accessed information; breach notification applies if electronic system breached. Electronic communication security: encryption required for information in transit; access controls required for electronic systems; authentication required (username/password minimum, MFA preferred); secure session management; data minimization for electronic access. Customer data protection: customer financial data protected when accessed electronically; account numbers, PINs, passwords protected; biometric data protected if used; transaction data protected; audit trails maintained for electronic access. Regulatory guidance: FTC guidance on electronic information security; Federal Reserve guidance on Internet banking; OCC guidance on electronic services; CFPB guidance on electronic consumer protection.

column13: GLBA Section 501 privacy safeguards apply to electronic services; GLBA Section 505 e-commerce standards; FTC Safeguards Rule applies to electronic information security; Federal Reserve guidance on electronic banking; OCC guidance on information security; CFPB guidance on electronic consumer protection; State laws on electronic transactions
column14: Mandatory compliance; electronic services subject to GLBA; security breaches of electronic systems trigger notification requirements; subject to examination; electronic service security directly affects exam findings
column15: Internet Banking Security: Connection Security: HTTPS encryption required for all banking website connections; SSL/TLS certificates required; certificate validity verified; browser security warnings avoided; no unencrypted connections; secure certificate management. Website Authentication: strong password requirements (minimum 8 characters, complexity); username separate from account number; password reset procedures; password expiration optional but recommended; account lockout after failed attempts; security questions for account recovery. Multi-Factor Authentication: MFA highly recommended for online banking; second factor: SMS code, email code, hardware token, biometric, app-based authentication; MFA for account changes; MFA for high-risk transactions. Session Management: session timeouts (typically 15-30 minutes inactivity); timeout warning before expiration; user logout requirement; secure session tokens; session encryption; protection against session hijacking. Account Access Controls: customer sees only their own accounts; no cross-customer access; appropriate authorization checking; role-based access controls; limited staff access with audit trail. Transaction Processing: transaction encryption; transaction confirmation; customer notification of transactions; fraud detection systems; transaction limits or velocity checks; customer dispute procedures. Customer Data Display: account numbers partially masked (last 4 digits visible); passwords never displayed; PINs never transmitted unencrypted; transaction history encrypted; statement data secured. Secure Messaging: if bank offers secure messaging; messages encrypted; authentication required; message retention policies; secure message deletion; audit trail of communications. Mobile Banking Security: Mobile App Security: app downloaded from official app stores only; app security tested; app encryption implemented; app authentication required; app session timeouts; app logout required. Mobile Device Security: guidance to customers on device security; password/PIN on device; biometric authentication; remote wipe capability; app security update notification. Mobile Transactions: transaction verification; authentication required for sensitive transactions; transaction limits; notification to customer; fraud detection; customer dispute procedures. Payment Systems: Payment Card Security: PCI DSS compliance for credit/debit card processing; no card number storage (if possible); tokenization of card data; encryption of transmission; compliance audits; vendor oversight. Electronic Funds Transfer: EFT encryption; EFT authentication; EFT authorization controls; recurring transfer setup; transfer approval; customer notification. Peer-to-Peer Payments: P2P system encryption; P2P authentication; P2P fraud detection; P2P limits; P2P dispute procedures; P2P confirmation requirements. Wire Transfers: wire instruction verification; wire authentication; wire confirmation; wire limits; wire fraud detection; wire customer notification. Digital Wallet Integration: digital wallet security; tokenization of payment information; authentication for digital transactions; fraud detection; customer notification. Account Opening Online: Online Account Opening Process: identity verification; address verification; tax ID verification; beneficial ownership identification; fraud detection; documentation retention. Customer Verification: knowledge-based authentication; document verification; biometric identification; video verification (for some accounts); database verification; credit bureau checks. Electronic Signature: electronic signature compliance; signature capture; authentication of signer; retention of signed documents; legal validity of electronic signatures. AML/KYC Procedures: customer identification and verification; beneficial ownership determination; AML screening; sanctions checking; transaction monitoring; customer due diligence; ongoing monitoring. Electronic Communications: Customer Notifications: electronic delivery of notices if customer agrees; notice of privacy policy changes; notice of service changes; notice of rates changes; notice of account activities; transaction notifications. Electronic Statements: electronic statement delivery option; eSign Act compliance; customer election for electronic; opt-out right; archival of statements; security of statement access; authentication for statement access. Alerts and Notifications: transaction alerts (large transactions, unusual activity); fraud alerts; system maintenance notifications; security alerts; breach notifications if applicable; opt-in/opt-out procedures. Electronic Correspondence: customer emails to bank encrypted (if possible); bank emails to customer; confidential data never via unencrypted email; secure portal preferred for sensitive communication; email retention policies. Electronic Services Outages: Continuity Planning: backup systems for electronic services; failover procedures; recovery time objectives; alternative customer access methods; customer notification of outages; status updates; ETA for restoration. Customer Communication: notification of outages; explanation of outage; expected duration; alternative access methods; compensation or rate adjustments if extended outage; post-outage customer communication. Data Backup: regular backups of electronic system data; offsite backup storage; backup encryption; backup testing; recovery procedures; backup security. Disaster Recovery: disaster recovery plan for electronic services; documented procedures; alternative processing sites; failover testing; recovery time objectives. Cybersecurity: Threat Detection: intrusion detection systems; intrusion prevention systems; malware detection; anomaly detection; log analysis; threat monitoring; security operations center. Vulnerability Management: vulnerability scanning (regular, automated); penetration testing (annual minimum); vulnerability assessment; patch management; timely patching; configuration management. Access Control Testing: periodic access control testing; privilege access management; access reviews; access removal when employee departs; segregation of duties; dual control for sensitive functions. Incident Response: incident response procedures for electronic systems breaches; detection procedures; containment procedures; investigation; notification; customer notification; regulatory notification if required. Customer Security Guidance: Education: customer education on phishing; customer education on password security; customer education on device security; customer education on social engineering; tips for secure banking; awareness materials. Fraud Prevention: fraud detection systems; suspicious activity monitoring; customer notification of suspicious activity; fraud dispute procedures; zero liability policies (where applicable); fraud prevention tips. Encryption Education: explanation of HTTPS; browser security indicators; explanation of MFA; explanation of digital signatures. Examination Focus: examiners assess electronic services security; test website security; review authentication procedures; assess encryption; review incident response; test fraud detection; assess customer notifications; review backup and disaster recovery; verify compliance with electronic banking guidance. Common Issues: inadequate encryption; weak authentication; no MFA; inadequate access controls; slow security patches; inadequate incident response; no backup procedures; inadequate customer notification; phishing vulnerability; weak password requirements.

node_name: Social Media and Digital Communication Privacy
definition: Privacy protections when financial institutions use social media platforms and digital communications for customer service and marketing. Includes disclosure of non-confidential nature of social media
organization_owner: Per FTC guidance and GLBA application to social media, financial institutions using social media platforms must: disclose that social media is not confidential channel; not encourage customers to send personal information via social media; direct sensitive communications to secure channels; protect any personal information posted; comply with GLBA privacy rules for digital communications; disclose social media policies to customers. Social media use by institutions: customer service support on social media platforms; marketing and product announcements; brand engagement; social listening (monitoring mentions); customer complaints resolution; community building. Privacy issues: social media not secure channel for personal information; platform terms of service create risks; data sharing with third parties; retention policies outside institution control; reputational risks; customer expectation of confidentiality not met; regulatory warnings about social media security.
version: All financial institutions using social media; any institution with Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, TikTok, Instagram, YouTube presence; any institution accepting customer service requests via social media; applies to all institution sizes; applies to all social media platforms
status: Chief Marketing Officer for social media strategy; Chief Privacy Officer for social media privacy; Compliance Officer for social media GLBA compliance; Social Media Manager for day-to-day management; Customer Service Manager for support via social media; Legal counsel for social media policies
key_features: GLBA Section 501 privacy safeguards; FTC guidance on social media financial institutions (FTC staff comments on privacy, 2011); Interagency guidance on social media risks; OCC guidance on social media; CFPB guidance on social media marketing; FTC endorsement guides for social media; State consumer protection laws on social media; Platform-specific policies
column11: Recommended practice; subject to examination if institution uses social media; privacy guidance applies to social media communications; institution liable for customer information posted on social media; examination will assess social media privacy practices
column12: Social Media Policy Development: Policy Scope: institution social media accounts covered; employee personal social media accounts if discussing institution/products; contractor social media if representing institution; customers representing themselves on institution accounts. Confidentiality Disclosure: clear disclosure that social media not confidential channel; warning against sending personal information; direction to secure channels for sensitive information; customer acknowledgment of risks; prominent placement of disclosure. Account Purposes: stated purpose of each social media account; customer service account for support; marketing account for promotions; corporate account for news/announcements; career recruiting account; investor relations account. Account Security: passwords managed securely; access limited to authorized employees; password changes when employee departs; two-factor authentication; audit log of account access; social media account recovery procedures. Content Management: what can be posted on institution accounts; what customers can post; moderation procedures; offensive content removal; spam removal; brand guidelines; approved messaging; review procedures. Customer Service via Social Media: Limitations: not for urgent issues (direct to phone); not for account changes (use secure portal); not for sensitive information; not for customer verification (no personal info sharing); not primary support channel. Appropriate Use: general questions; account information inquiries (no account numbers); product information; complaint escalation; lost card reporting (with proper verification); service requests (basic information only). Response Procedures: timely response to customer inquiries; professional tone; brand consistency; escalation procedures for complex issues; documentation of interactions; customer satisfaction tracking. Privacy Considerations: direct sensitive questions to secure channel; don't request personal information via social media; don't verify identity via social media; no account numbers in public posts; delete sensitive information; audit trail of interactions. Direct Message (DM) Handling: use DM for sensitive information transfer if necessary; verify customer identity before sending account information; restrict who can send DMs; monitor DMs for fraud; escalate to secure channel for account changes; document all DM interactions. Customer Complaints: respond promptly; escalate to appropriate department; offer offline resolution channel; maintain confidentiality; follow complaint procedures; document resolution; avoid public disputes. Brand Reputation Management: monitor mentions of institution; respond to false information; address complaints professionally; avoid controversial topics; maintain institutional voice; monitor influencers/reporters. Employee Social Media Use: Employee Guidelines: employees should not represent institution on personal accounts without disclosure; employees should not share confidential information on social media; employees should not direct customers to personal accounts; employees training required; consequences for violations; separation procedures. Personal Account Protections: employees educated on phishing via social media; employees educated on social engineering; employees educated on information sharing risks; privacy settings on personal accounts. Separation Procedures: when employee departs, remove access to institution accounts; remove from group chats; retrieve passwords; monitor former employee social media for compliance. Customer Data Protection: Data Minimization: minimize customer data on social media platform; no account numbers; no full SSNs; no full address; no sensitive health information; only necessary information. Data Retention: institution data not retained on social media platform; institution periodically cleans up old posts; customer messages archived off-platform; backup procedures; deletion procedures. Third-Party Data Sharing: understand platform data sharing practices; platform may use data for advertising; platform may sell data to third parties; institution discloses in privacy notice; customer opt-out if available. Customer Privacy Settings: assist customers in securing their personal social media accounts; provide guidance on privacy settings; explain platform data collection; explain targeted advertising; direct customers to platform privacy policies. Data Breach Notification: if customer data posted publicly; assess whether disclosure; notification procedures if required; remediation; removal of information. Influencer and Third-Party Partnerships: Vetting: vet influencers before partnerships; assess audience alignment; assess brand fit; assess influencer reputation; assess for fraud/scams; legal review. Disclosure Requirements: influencers must disclose sponsored posts; hashtags (#ad, #sponsored) required; clear and conspicuous disclosure; FTC Endorsement Guides compliance; disclosures per platform requirements. Contracts: partnership agreements address data handling; data protection; confidentiality; brand standards; approval of content; liability; termination procedures. Monitoring: monitor influencer posts; ensure disclosure compliance; ensure accurate information; ensure brand consistency; ensure no GLBA violations; customer complaints tracking. Marketing and Promotions: Promotional Posts: clear disclosures of terms and conditions; no misleading information; accuracy in product descriptions; rate information current and accurate; no false claims; compliance with truth in advertising. Targeted Advertising: understand platform targeting capabilities; target appropriate demographic; avoid predatory lending; avoid discrimination; fair lending compliance; TILA/RESPA compliance if applicable. Sweepstakes and Contests: legal compliance with contest rules; no false promises; clear eligibility; transparent winner selection; data collection compliant; privacy of entrant data; tax reporting. Compliance Monitoring: Content Review: regular review of institution posts; accuracy verification; brand consistency; legal compliance; GLBA compliance; FTC Act compliance. Customer Communications: monitor customer comments on posts; respond appropriately; escalate complaints; document interactions; protect customer privacy in responses. Metrics and Analytics: track engagement metrics; monitor sentiment; customer satisfaction; track customer service resolution; assess effectiveness; privacy-compliant analytics. Policy Updates: policies reviewed annually; updated for new platforms; updated for regulatory changes; updated for incident learnings; staff retrained; policy changes documented. Examination Focus: examiners assess social media policies; review for privacy disclosures; assess customer data protection; review customer service procedures; test confidentiality warnings; assess employee compliance; review incident response; identify GLBA violations. Common Issues: no confidentiality warnings; customer personal information on social media; inadequate moderation; no customer data protection; employee misuse of accounts; influencer violations; inadequate social media policies; GLBA violations on social media.

node_name: Emerging Technology and Innovation in Financial Services
definition: GLBA compliance for emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence
key_features: and regulatory consideration for new service delivery methods.
column11: Per GLBA and emerging technology guidance, financial institutions adopting new technologies must maintain GLBA compliance for customer information regardless of technology used. Emerging technologies require: privacy impact assessment; security assessment; third-party assessment if using third-party providers; customer disclosure; regulatory compliance; incident response procedures; backup and recovery; business continuity; compliance documentation. Technologies addressed: artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML); blockchain and cryptocurrencies; open banking APIs; biometric authentication; cloud computing; distributed systems; advanced analytics; robo-advisors; digital currencies; fintech partnerships.
